title.en: Anti-colonial Resistance in South Africa and Israel/Palestine: Identity, Nationalism, and Race
Palestine

summary.en:
Azmi Bishara’s Palestine: Matters of Truth and Justice is essential reading for understanding Palestine today. Initially, the book was supposed to be an English translation of a lecture on what Bishara calls the Trump–Netanyahu deal. Fortunately for the English reader, the lecture is now upgraded with eight chapters that build on decades of Bishara’s political and intellectual engagement with the question of Palestine. These chapters contextualize Trump’s so-called “deal of the century” within the longer history of the region and its geopolitical transformations. The task is ambitious but wonderfully executed. One leaves the book with a deeper understanding of contemporary developments, informed by the weight of history, and with a vision for justice in Palestine/Israel.

Addressing all these dimensions in one symposium, let alone one contribution, is impossible. I will therefore focus on a specific topic that runs through the book, namely, the politics of memory in Palestine/Israel. In his introduction, Bishara notes that the book's different themes will be discussed in conjunction "with the questions of memory and forgetting" (p. 9). Below I will discuss four of these themes: the theoretical framework of settler colonialism, Bishara’s analysis of the Trump–Netanyahu deal, Palestinian resistance to the deal, and Bishara’s vision of justice in Palestine/Israel.

title.en: Settler colonialism, memory politics, and the Trump–Netanyahu deal
Memory and Forgetting in the Israeli–Palestinian Peace Process

place: FAIR Ethics in Peace Negotiations. Podcast (Spotify/Apple)

summary.en: This case brief examines how the Israeli–Palestinian peace process dealt with radical disagreements over collective memory. It identifies three positions taken towards this specific issue: prescriptive forgetting that avoids the past altogether, strategic forgetting that postpones dealing with it, and transitional justice that recommends addressing it head-on. The first two approaches fit within the framework of the Oslo accords that was characterized by its pragmatic and gradualist approach to negotiations. Transitional justice, on the other hand, was absent from the peace process and was typically endorsed by its critics who insisted on the need to deal with the past. This case brief looks at how these different approaches played out during the peace process, focusing mostly on the period stretching from 1993 to 2001. It concludes by discussing some implications for the ethics of peace negotiations.

title.en: Memory and Forgetting at the Negotiating Table: The Case of the Israeli–Palestinian Peace Process (1993–2001)
Israel and Palestinian Peoplehood: The Power to Eliminate and the Power to Constitute
Transitional Justice in Palestine/Israel: Whose Justice? Which Transition?

arranged_by.name: Pluralism, Democracy, and Justice research group

summary.en: National narratives are an essential part of the Israeli–Palestinian conflict. Little is said, however, on how the Oslo Peace Process sought to address these narratives. Conventional wisdom argues that the peace process initiated in the 1990s largely ignored the matter. This article challenges this view, arguing instead that the peace process was and continues to be actively engaged in solving the narrative wars that divide Israelis and Palestinians. To shed light on these solutions, this article looks beyond the agreements of the Oslo Peace Process and focuses on the peacebuilding paradigms that informed it, more specifically, the national partition and the liberal peace paradigms. These prescribe two solutions to the Israeli–Palestinian conflict over history: narrative partition and evasion. In their implementation, the article concludes, these solutions imposed greater identity costs on the Palestinian narrative than on the Israeli one.

title.en: National narratives and the Oslo peace process: How peacebuilding paradigms address conflicts over history
Group differentiated rights and the rights of the past

event.name: Minority rights, global institutions, and cultural justice

title.en: Law and narrative: the registers of normative discourse

event.name: International Congress on Narrative Social Science

summary.en: Identity based	conflicts abound in today’s international system. Whether	 it be in Israel-Palestine,	Cyprus,	or the Balkans,	national	identities fuel	wars	that, to	many,seem	 intractable. Because	 they	 are	 a	 crucial	 part	 of	 the	 problem,	 scholars argue,national	identities should	be	an	important	part	of	the	solution.	National	identities,	they	recommend, should be	negotiated so	as to	reach a	“narrative	equilibrium” thatwill allow	past	enemies	to overcome	national	stereotypes, build	trust, and	sustainpeaceful	relations in	the	future.	This	paper	does	not	evaluate	the	merits	of	these	negotiations,	but the	tools	social	scientists have employed	to analyze them. Its	main	purpose,	 therefore,	 is methodological. It	 argues	 that	 attempts	 to	 theorize	 the	negotiation	of	identity in	post	conflict	scenarios fall	short	of	their	goal, because	they	focus solely	on	the	notion of	negotiation—understood	in	rational	terms—and very	little	on the	concept	of	identity. To	remedy	this	shortcoming,	the	paper turns	to thestructural	theories	of	narrative	to conceptualize the	negotiation	of	identity	as the	negotiation	 of	 plot	 structures. It	 argues that	 identity based	 conflicts	 are	 better	understood	 as	 two	 mutually	 exclusive	 romantic	 plots. The negotiation	 of	 identitytherefore	is	the	attempt	to	move	from	dueling	romantic	plots	to	tragic,	comic,	or	satiric narratives	 in	 equilibrium.	 The	 introduction	 of	 plot	 structures,	 the	 paperconcludes,	 is	 essential	 to	 theorize	 the	 negotiation	 of	 identity	 in	 post-conflict	scenarios.

title.en: The negotiation of identity as a negotiation of plot-structures: attempt at a methodology

arranged_by.name: Alliance for historical dialogue and accountability

summary.en: The purpose of this article is to examine the undervalued and marginalized position of narratives in mainstream political theory today. Why are narratives an inferior way of thinking about normative issues? Why are they absent from predominant ways of answering normative questions about politics? This article argues that such an undervalued position can be best explained by the predominance of a nomological approach in mainstream political theory. By a nomological approach, I mean a preference for law-like statements (prescriptive laws, principles, norms, rules),  so that questions about what we ought to do are answered nomologically. The all affected principle, the difference principle, the categorical imperative, or the laws of nature are examples of such law-like statements that are familiar to researchers in political theory. A preoccupation with these prescriptive laws— their origin, their justification, their legitimacy, their scope of application, their internal constituency, and their relationship to other principles—constitutes the primary focus of political theorists. The primacy of the nomological approach, I want to argue, downplays the value of narratives. The uneven and asymmetrical relationship that I want to highlight is one between laws and narrative. Narratives have an undervalued position in political theory because law-like formulations have a privileged position. The strength of the latter is relative to the weakness of the former and vice versa. I trace this nomological preference to the influence of positivist social science, analytic philosophy, and liberalism on the discipline of political theory. While these three stress different kinds of laws (causal laws, prescriptive laws, and formal legalism) they contribute to the nomological bias in political theory.

title.en: "We do not want yo hear your story": political theory's nomological bias

arranged_by.name: Department of political science, University of Oslo

summary.en:
The focus of this paper is the figure of the disabled in Palestinian national memory. Disability is a common phenomenon in Palestine. Many are disabled because they incurred injuries in clashes with the Israeli army. The First Intifada, most notoriously, left behind scores of disabled Palestinians after Israeli soldiers were instructed to “break the arms and legs” of stone throwers. More recently, the Gaza war of summer 2014 left 2000 dead and over 11,000 injured. The Palestinian Central Bureau of Statistics predicts that 1,134 of these injured will remain disabled for life. While they constitute an important part of those who struggle against and suffer from Israeli occupation, the injured and disabled have no place in Palestinian national memory. The aim of this paper is to examine why.  

Like other national struggles, the Palestinian body politic sustains itself through the commemoration of some of its parts. These include the martyr, the fighter, the prisoner, the statesman, the refugee, the intellectual and the peasant. These figures play an important role in Palestinian commemorative practices, because they embody the struggle for self-determination. All have paid a heavy price for their action, be it dispossession, exile, imprisonment, or death. But while there are museums dedicated to prisoners and posters commemorating martyrs, there is nothing for the disabled. Why do death or imprisonment grant entry into a nation’s collective memory, while injury and disability do not? Situated at the intersection of critical disability and memory studies—especially the works of Nancy Hirschmann and Paul Connerton—and building on a series of interviews conducted in May 2014 with Palestinians who suffered from disabling injuries, the paper examines three possible reasons. The first is implied by the logic of nationalism itself. From this perspective, the disabled body clashes with the able-body of the national hero (alive or dead), leaving the disabled outside the pantheon of national figures. The second explanation is ethical. Commemorating the disabled runs the risk of permanently reminding the disabled of his condition. Instead of memory, the disabled are owed support.  The third explanation, which this paper defends, argues that there is some truth to both positions. What they miss, however, is the fact that the bodies of the disabled operate themselves as spaces of memory. They also operate as spaces of forgetfulness, for the disabled individual wants to forget about his injury (a physical and psychological trauma), and the community wants to forget the victimizer’s mark on his disabled body. The paper concludes with a series of commemorative dilemmas: how do we pay respect for the disabled who risked parts of their bodies for a political cause? How can the disabled reclaim a body that carries the mark of the victimizer?

title.en: Disabled memories: remembering/forgetting the injured in Occupied palestine

arranged_by.name: Pluralism, Democracy and Justice research group
